issues.description: The UML in the problem statement defines the Ride attribute as 'shortCode: char' (and therefore students will expect a getter named getShortCode()). The solution implementation instead names this attribute 'abbreviation' with a getter getAbbreviation(). This is a structural naming mismatch between the specification (UML/problem statement) and the provided solution. Students following the UML literally will create a field/getter named shortCode/getShortCode which will differ from the reference implementation and could cause confusion or test mismatches.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute name consistent across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution to use the UML name 'shortCode' and provide a getter getShortCode(), or (B) update the UML/problem statement to name the attribute 'abbreviation' (and update any task descriptions that mention the attribute). Ensure the getter name matches the chosen attribute name (for a char attribute 'shortCode' use getShortCode()).

issues.description: The UML in the problem statement defines a Ride attribute named 'shortCode: char' but the solution implementation names the corresponding attribute 'abbreviation' (with getter getAbbreviation()). This is a naming mismatch for the same conceptual entity (a short code/abbreviation identifying the ride). Because the exercise instructs students to create attributes and getters exactly as in the UML, this divergence can create unnecessary mapping confusion and lead to mismatches with expected attribute/getter names.
issues.suggested_fix: Use the same identifier across artifacts. Either (A) change the solution implementation to name the field and getter 'shortCode' (private char shortCode; public char getShortCode()) and adjust constructor parameter name accordingly, or (B) update the UML/problem statement to use 'abbreviation' consistently. Option A is recommended to match the UML as presented to students.
